WormInfestations.name: Roundworm (Ascariasis)
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, a large roundworm (~15–30 cm)
Transmission: Feco-oral route via ingestion of embryonated eggs in contaminated food or water
Life cycle:
1. Eggs swallowed → hatch in small intestine
2. Larvae penetrate intestinal wall → migrate via blood to lungs
3. Ascend respiratory tract → swallowed again → mature in intestine
Matures into adult worms in ~2 months
mode_of_transmission: Ingestion of infective eggs from contaminated hands, soil, food
Associated with poor hygiene and sanitation

Pulmonary Phase (Larval migration): Löffler’s syndrome: dry cough, wheezing, dyspnea, fever, eosinophilia
Intestinal Phase (Adult worms): Malnutrition and growth retardation in chronic cases
Intestinal obstruction (esp. in high worm load)
Passing worms in stool or vomitus
Appendicitis, biliary obstruction, or pancreatitis (migration to ducts)

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_clues: Localized RLQ pain, no worm history
Colicky pain with vomiting, may mimic high worm load

diagnosis: Stool microscopy: ova detection (fertilized/unfertilized eggs)
CBC: eosinophilia (esp. in pulmonary phase)
Abdominal X-ray/USG: may show worms in obstruction
Sputum exam: may rarely show larvae in early phase

General: Mebendazole 100 mg BID × 3 days (or single 500 mg dose)

complications: Malnutrition, anemia (less common than in hookworm)
Respiratory distress in heavy larval migration
prevention: Handwashing with soap before eating, after defecation
Proper food hygiene: washing vegetables, boiling water
Avoid open defecation, use of sanitary toilets
Health education on hygiene practices

National Deworming Day (India): Observed on February 10th and repeat on August 10th; Albendazole 400 mg given to all children (1–19 years); Part of government’s strategy to reduce worm burden & malnutrition

WormInfestations.name: Pinworm (Enterobiasis)
WormInfestations.description: A common helminthic infection in children caused by Enterobius vermicularis, known for intense perianal itching, especially at night
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Enterobius vermicularis, a small white roundworm (~1 cm)
Transmission: Feco-oral route (autoinfection common)
Lifecycle:
1. Eggs ingested → hatch in small intestine
2. Adults reside in cecum & colon
3. Gravid female worms migrate at night to perianal region → lay eggs
4. Eggs become infective in hours and cause itching
5. Scratching → eggs under nails → autoinfection or person-to-person spread
mode_of_transmission: Direct: hand-to-mouth from contaminated fingers (especially due to scratching)
Indirect: contaminated clothing, bedding, toilet seats
Highly contagious in households, schools, daycare
WormInfestations.infective_period: As long as eggs are shed (several weeks unless treated); High reinfection risk due to autoinfection

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_clues: Dysuria, discharge, odor in urine/genital tract
No worms or eggs, emotional triggers

diagnosis: Scotch tape test: Early morning perianal swab using transparent tape; Microscopic exam reveals oval, flattened-sided eggs
Direct worm visualization at night near anus
Routine stool exam is often negative

Medication: Treat entire household to prevent reinfection
Albendazole 400 mg single dose (repeat after 2 weeks)
Alternatives: Mebendazole 100 mg single dose or Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg (max 1 g) — single dose
Symptom relief: Antihistamines or topical soothing agents for itching

complications: Sleep disturbance, behavioral issues in chronic cases
Vulvovaginitis or urinary tract infection (rare but possible)
prevention: Trim fingernails short
Daily morning baths, especially of perianal area
Handwashing after toilet use, before meals
Wash clothes, bedding, underwear in hot water
Educate about avoiding nail-biting and scratching

WormInfestations.name: Hookworm Infection
WormInfestations.description: A helminthic infection caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus, leading to chronic blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia, especially in children
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus
Transmission: skin penetration by filariform larvae in contaminated soil
Life cycle:
1. Larvae penetrate skin (usually feet) → enter bloodstream
2. Migrate to lungs → trachea → swallowed
3. Mature into adult worms in small intestine
4. Feed on mucosa → cause chronic blood loss
A. duodenale causes more blood loss than N. americanus
WormInfestations.incubation_period: 4–8 weeks from skin penetration to egg shedding in stool
WormInfestations.infective_period: Humans are infective as long as adult worms produce eggs; Adult worms may live for 1–2 years

Skin Phase: Ground itch: localized rash at entry site (itching, redness)
Pulmonary Phase: Dry cough, wheeze, eosinophilia (similar to Löffler’s syndrome)
Intestinal Phase: Chronic blood loss → iron deficiency anemia
Pallor, fatigue, delayed milestones, poor school performance

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Steatorrhea, weight loss, no anemia usually

diagnosis: Stool microscopy: Detects oval, thin-shelled eggs
CBC: Microcytic hypochromic anemia; Eosinophilia
Peripheral smear: to rule out other causes of anemia
treatment: Albendazole 400 mg single dose or Mebendazole 100 mg BID × 3 days
Iron and folic acid supplementation if anemia present
complications: Cognitive and growth delay in children
prevention: Wearing footwear in endemic areas
Avoiding open defecation
Sanitary disposal of feces
Hand and foot hygiene
Health education

WormInfestations.name: Cutaneous Larva Migrans (CLM)
WormInfestations.description: A creeping skin eruption caused by migration of hookworm larvae (animal origin) within the epidermis — also called "creeping eruption"
etiopathogenesis: Caused by larvae of animal hookworms — mainly: Ancylostoma braziliense (cats, dogs), Ancylostoma caninum (dogs)
Humans = accidental host
Larvae penetrate skin but can’t complete their lifecycle → remain trapped in skin and migrate
Found in warm, moist sandy environments (beaches, sandpits, gardens)
WormInfestations.mode_of_transmission: Direct skin contact with soil or sand contaminated by feces of infected animals; Walking barefoot, sitting or lying on ground = common exposure
WormInfestations.incubation_period: Few days to a week after exposure
WormInfestations.infective_period: No human-to-human transmission; Not systemically infective in humans
clinical_features: Itchy, serpiginous, raised, red lesion — pathognomonic
Lesion appears as creeping, snake-like track
Common sites: feet, buttocks, thighs, hands
Secondary bacterial infection due to scratching may occur

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Burrows in web spaces, generalized itch
Round lesions with scaling and central clearing
Rapidly moving linear rash, perianal focus

diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on typical appearance and history of exposure
No need for biopsy or imaging in most cases
Blood: eosinophilia may be present (mild)

First-line: Or Ivermectin 200 mcg/kg once daily × 1–2 days

prevention: Wear footwear and protective clothing on sand/soil
Avoid sitting or lying directly on beach or garden soil
Proper disposal of pet feces
Deworming of pets
Hygiene education in endemic areas

WormInfestations.name: Strongyloidiasis
WormInfestations.description: An intestinal nematode infection caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, notable for autoinfection, chronicity, and potential for hyperinfection in immunocompromised hosts
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, a small intestinal nematode
Unique feature: can replicate inside the human host via autoinfection
Lifecycle:
1. Filariform larvae penetrate skin (usually feet) → enter bloodstream
2. Travel to lungs, ascend trachea, swallowed → reach small intestine
3. Mature into adult female worms → lay eggs that hatch into rhabditiform larvae
4. These may be:
• Excreted in stool, or
• Transform into filariform larvae in gut → autoinfection
Autoinfection → chronic infection lasting decades
mode_of_transmission: Skin penetration by larvae from contaminated soil
Common in barefoot walking, poor hygiene areas
Autoinfection allows lifelong infection if untreated
WormInfestations.incubation_period: 1–3 weeks from exposure to symptom onset
WormInfestations.infective_period: Potentially lifelong due to autoinfection; Risk of hyperinfection in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., steroids, HIV, malignancy)

Skin Phase: Itchy, red rash at penetration site (often on feet)
Pulmonary Phase: Dry cough, wheezing, fever, Löffler’s syndrome
Intestinal Phase: Abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea or constipation

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Chronic symptoms, negative stool for larvae

diagnosis: Stool microscopy: rhabditiform larvae (may require multiple samples)
Concentration techniques improve yield
Duodenal aspirate or biopsy (for definitive diagnosis)
Eosinophilia (common but not always present)
Serology (ELISA) helpful in chronic infection
Sputum or BAL: larvae in hyperinfection
treatment: Treat even asymptomatic cases due to autoinfection risk
First-line: Ivermectin 200 mcg/kg/day × 1–2 days (repeat in 2 weeks if needed)
In hyperinfection: continue daily until symptoms and larvae resolve
Alternative: Albendazole 400 mg BID × 7 days (less effective)
complications: Sepsis, meningitis (due to gut flora translocation)
Death in disseminated cases (esp. if immunocompromised)
prevention: Wearing footwear outdoors
Proper sanitation and hygiene
Avoid barefoot walking in endemic areas
Screening before steroid or immunosuppressive therapy
Early treatment to prevent chronic carriage

WormInfestations.name: Whipworm (Trichuriasis)
WormInfestations.description: A soil-transmitted helminthic infection caused by Trichuris trichiura, primarily affecting the large intestine, leading to diarrhea, rectal prolapse, and anemia in children
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Trichuris trichiura, a whip-shaped nematode (~4 cm)
Transmission: feco-oral route by ingesting embryonated eggs from contaminated food, water, or soil
Lifecycle:
1. Eggs swallowed → hatch in small intestine
2. Larvae migrate to cecum and ascending colon
3. Burrow into mucosa and mature into adult worms
4. Females lay thousands of eggs daily, passed in stool
Heavy infections → mucosal damage, inflammation, bleeding
mode_of_transmission: Ingestion of infective eggs from contaminated soil, water, or hands
Related to poor sanitation, open defecation, and geophagia
WormInfestations.infective_period: As long as adult worms remain in the colon (can live up to 1–3 years); No autoinfection

Symptomatic Cases (moderate to heavy wor: Chronic diarrhea (may contain blood and mucus)
Rectal prolapse — characteristic in severe pediatric cases
Clubbing, pallor, poor school performance in chronic disease

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Acute onset, fever, more severe systemic illness

diagnosis: Stool microscopy: Shows characteristic barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs
CBC: May show eosinophilia, hypochromic anemia
Proctoscopy (rarely needed): may visualize worms in mucosa
Multiple stool samples may be needed to detect eggs
treatment: Treat all symptomatic patients and heavy worm carriers
First-line: Albendazole 400 mg once daily × 3 days or Mebendazole 100 mg BID × 3 days (less effective as single dose)
Supportive: Iron and nutritional supplements if anemic or undernourished
prevention: Hand hygiene before eating, after defecation
Proper washing of vegetables and fruits
Safe drinking water
Avoid open defecation, use toilets
Deworming programs in schools and communities

WormInfestations.name: Taeniasis
WormInfestations.description: Intestinal infection caused by adult tapeworms (Taenia solium or Taenia saginata)
etiopathogenesis: Caused by: Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) or Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)
Humans are definitive hosts for adult worms
Lifecycle: Eating undercooked meat containing larval cysts → larvae develop into adult worms in small intestine
WormInfestations.mode_of_transmission: Eating undercooked infected pork (T. solium) or beef (T. saginata)
WormInfestations.infective_period: Adult worms may live for years; Eggs shed in stool are immediately infective to others
clinical_features: May have: Abdominal discomfort, bloating, nausea
Passage of proglottids (worm segments) in stool

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Larger worm expelled, no cystic phase

diagnosis: Stool exam: eggs or gravid proglottids
Microscopy: may differentiate T. saginata vs T. solium
treatment: Albendazole 400 mg or Praziquantel 10 mg/kg – single dose
prevention: Proper cooking of meat (esp. pork and beef)
Personal hygiene: handwashing, nail trimming
Sanitation: use of latrines, avoid open defecation
Meat inspection before sale
Treat infected individuals to prevent egg spread

WormInfestations.name: Cysticercosis
WormInfestations.description: A tissue parasitic infection caused by the larval stage (cysticercus) of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium, with the brain being the most commonly affected organ (Neurocysticercosis)
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Taenia solium eggs (not larvae)
Feco-oral transmission: ingestion of eggs through contaminated food/water or autoinfection from a tapeworm carrier
Eggs hatch → larvae (oncospheres) penetrate intestinal mucosa → disseminate hematogenously → form cysticerci in tissues
Common sites: Brain (Neurocysticercosis – NCC), Muscles, Eyes, Subcutaneous tissue
WormInfestations.mode_of_transmission: Ingestion of Taenia solium eggs from contaminated hands, vegetables, water; Autoinfection from taeniasis
WormInfestations.incubation_period: Weeks to months after exposure; Clinical presentation depends on cyst location and immune response
WormInfestations.infective_period: Not transmissible from cysticercosis patient to others; Person with intestinal Taenia solium (taeniasis) can shed infective eggs

Neurocysticercosis (Most common & severe: Cognitive changes or psychiatric symptoms in chronic cases
Extraneural Cysticercosis: Ocular cysts: floaters, visual loss, retinal detachment

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: History of TB, ring lesions, Mantoux positive
Fever, rapid deterioration, pus on imaging
Liver/lung focus, larger cysts, no scolex

diagnosis: Neuroimaging (CT/MRI): Ring-enhancing lesions, cysts with scolex (dot sign); Multiple stages: vesicular, colloidal, granular, calcified
Serology (ELISA, EITB) for T. solium antibodies
Ophthalmologic exam if eye involvement suspected
Histopathology of nodules (if accessible) confirms diagnosis
CSF: may show mild lymphocytic pleocytosis, eosinophilia, ↑ protein (in NCC)

Antiparasitic: Albendazole 15 mg/kg/day × 7–28 days or Praziquantel 50–75 mg/kg/day × 15–30 days
Usually combined with steroids to reduce inflammatory response
Corticosteroids: Dexamethasone or Prednisolone to prevent seizures & edema
Antiepileptics: For seizure control — valproate, phenytoin, etc.
Continue until lesion resolution or calcification
Surgery: Eye cyst excision (avoid antiparasitics if intraocular)

complications: Death in severe untreated CNS involvement
prevention: Cook pork thoroughly
Handwashing after defecation, before meals
Proper sanitation and sewage disposal
Treatment of taeniasis carriers to stop egg shedding
Public awareness in endemic areas

WormInfestations.name: Scarabiasis
WormInfestations.description: Also known as beetle infestation, Scarabiasis is a rare condition caused by the accidental passage or infestation of beetles (especially Blaps species) in the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract, mostly in children
etiopathogenesis: Caused by ingestion or entry of beetles, especially from Scarab beetle group
Common species: Blaps spp., Tenebrio molitor
Beetles may enter:
• Gastrointestinal tract (through ingestion of contaminated food)
• Genitourinary tract (through crawling into body openings, especially in children or bedridden patients)
Rarely, beetles may remain alive and cause mechanical irritation or trauma
mode_of_transmission: Accidental ingestion of beetles or beetle larvae in contaminated food/water
Direct entry into body orifices (anus, vagina, urethra) while sleeping on the ground
More common in poor hygiene and rural areas
WormInfestations.incubation_period: No true incubation; symptoms occur shortly after infestation
WormInfestations.infective_period: Not contagious; Involves individual exposure only
clinical_features: Passing of live beetles in stool or urine (alarming to parents)
Dysuria or vaginal irritation if beetles enter genitourinary tract
Mild diarrhea or discomfort may be present
Often asymptomatic except for passage of beetle

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_features: Nighttime itching, microscopic eggs in tape test

diagnosis: Clinical observation of beetle or larvae in stool/urine
Microscopic identification of species
Stool exam may be normal otherwise
treatment: Topical soothing agents if local irritation present
complications: Rare: secondary infections due to scratching
prevention: Proper food storage and hygiene
Avoid sleeping directly on the ground
Clean bedding and clothes
Insect control in homes, especially in rural areas
